info.game_comments: 2005 Ultimate Tournament of Champions Round 2, game 5.

(1, 1).clue: The Art Institute of Chicago is guarded by 2 of these beasts (bronze ones, not real ones)

(2, 1).clue: You might want to take a water taxi to this city's Piazza San Marco but--mamma mia!--it can be pricey

(3, 1).clue: This common name for a cow is also an adjective that means "overly authoritative"

(4, 1).clue: "I have given up newspapers... for Tacitus and Thucydides... and I find myself much the happier", said this U.S. pres.

(5, 1).clue: Nestle introduced this drink product in 1948 to compete with Ovaltine

(6, 1).clue: John Lithgow & Norbert Leo Butz conned their way onto Broadway as the title rogues in "Dirty Rotten" these

(1, 2).clue: In 2005, a search for "Chicago's Fairest Colleen" chose Bridget McLaughlin to reign over this parade

(2, 2).clue: Even when you think it's too expensive, the price you pay to ride in a cab is called by this homophone

(3, 2).clue: If cows went surfing, they'd probably yell this 9-letter word that starts with "cow", dude

(4, 2).clue: He had the "Common Sense" to idolize Ben Franklin, who encouraged his move to America in 1774

(5, 2).clue: Elizabeth Hooton was one of the first female preachers of this religious group

(6, 2).clue: Tim Curry & David Hyde Pierce star in this Monty Python inspired show

(1, 3).clue: Untouchable Tours visits such sanguineous spots as the site of this February 1929 event

(2, 3).clue: Often seen in Central Park, this conveyance gets part of its name from the Latin word for "foot"

(3, 3).clue: In the theme song of this classic TV Western, Frankie Laine sang, "Head 'em up, move 'em on"

(4, 3).clue: Since childhood, this author of "I Am Charlotte Simmons" has been a huge fan of a book called "Honey Bear"

(5, 3).clue: This luxury liner moored in Long Beach, Calif. is said to be haunted by a mysterious woman in white

(6, 3).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reads from the Gershwin Theatre in New York: "I'm on the Broadway set of Wicked.")  In 2004, this young actress defied gravity & flew off with a Tony award for her performance as a witch in "Wicked"

(1, 4).clue: Shoppers adore "The Magnificent Mile", the north part of this avenue

(2, 4).clue: Cab drivers came to be called hacks because of this old word for a coach for hire

(3, 4).clue: Range Riders Ranch in this state offers a cattle drive vacation along the old Bozeman Trail

(4, 4).clue: This "Jude the Obscure" author admired Browning but was said to be too shy to meet him

(5, 4).clue: He was Norway's minister of defense from 1931 to 1933

(6, 4).clue: An off-Broadway hit in 1987 & then a film, this play set in a Louisiana beauty parlor finally blossomed on B'way in 2005

(1, 5).clue: At Shedd Aquarium these white whales are such good vocalizers that you may feel they're talking to you

(2, 5).clue: "Cab" is a shortened form of this 4-syllable French word for a light one-horse carriage

(3, 5).clue: By definition, cattle that are described as "polled" lack these

(4, 5).clue: This Scot's famous 1840s lectures on heroes & hero worship featured Odin & Rousseau

(5, 5).clue: When medium-sized, these hard clams are marketed as cherrystones

(6, 5).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reads from the Golden Theatre in New York with a special friend.)  In the Broadway hit "Avenue Q", Nicky here sings about this German word that means happiness at the misfortune of others

(1, 1).clue: 1-word name of the brain disease marked by delusions that's the largest cause of admission to mental hospitals

(2, 1).clue: As fun-loving businessman Thornton Melon, Rodney returned to college to help out his son in this comedy

(4, 1).clue: This name of a "Sound of Music" actor has the same origin as the job of fixing pipes

(5, 1).clue: The largest city by population is this capital with about 35 million

(6, 1).clue: Abbreviated Mlle, it's the French equivalent of Miss

(1, 2).clue: Giving a treat to a rat after it presses a bar is this type of "reinforcement"

(2, 2).clue: In "Ladybugs", a flustered Rodney coached a girls' team in this sport

(4, 2).clue: This one-syllable bookish-sounding name goes back to young attendants of lords

(5, 2).clue: In Turkish this capital is known as known as Lefkosa; in Greek it's known as Levkosia

(6, 2).clue: Postal abbreviation of the state whose largest city is Burlington

(1, 3).clue: Psychologist Carl Rogers favored this word over "patient"; perhaps he counted his billable hours

(2, 3).clue: In a rare dramatic turn, Rodney starred as an abusive father in this film about a murderous couple

(4, 3).clue: This common English last name indicates an ancestor who rounded wood on a lathe

(5, 3).clue: Founded in the 13th century, it's the capital & largest city of Laos

(6, 3).clue: In Internet addresses, zw stands for this country

(1, 4).clue: In the mind, it's coming to associate a behavior with a stimulus; in the body, it helps you get in shape

(2, 4).clue: Rodney's real last name, it means "priest" in Hebrew

(4, 4).clue: Schneider is German for this professional, & a Schneiderpuppe is his dummy

(5, 4).clue: No longer Alma-Ata, the capital city of this central Asian country is now Astana

(6, 4).clue: 4-letter abbreviation for the agency that investigates all the USA's civil aviation accidents

(1, 5).clue: Behaviorist Clark Hull reduced motivations to needs like hunger, which he gave this "transporting" term

(2, 5).clue: Popular comedians helped along by Rodney include Jerry Seinfeld, Jim Carrey, Tim Allen & this late ex-preacher

(4, 5).clue: This name of a great opera composer could be anglicized as Wainwright

(5, 5).clue: Situated on the Hrazdan River, this Armenian capital city is a mere 14 miles from the border with Turkey

(6, 5).clue: TVP, which stands for this, is a soybean product used as a food extender & is often used in faux hot dogs

(0, 0).clue: A top member of the Reagan Cabinet, he was also Labor Secretary & Treasury Secretary under Richard Nixon
